title: State/Identify
prompt: State the bus that carries a read signal to main memory
answer: Control Bus

title: State/identify
prompt: State the bus that carries the memory location of a piece of data
answer: Address Bus

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the bus that carries an instruction from main memory to the CPU
answer: Data Bus

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the component inside the CPU that stores data.
answer: Register

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the component that stored data and instrutions of currently running programs.
answer: Main memory

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the component of the CPU that carries out additions and comparisons.
answer: Arithmetic logic unit

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the component inside the CPU that provides the timing signals to synchronise operations.
answer: Clock

title: Describe
prompt: One function of an operating system is to manage processes.Describe one way the operating system makes sure each process can use the CPU.
answer:
• A scheduler/scheduling algorithm controls processes
• Each process gets a time slice/small amount of (CPU) time
• Processes are held in a data structure
• Each process may be held in order / priority
• Incomplete processes go to the back of the queue

title: State/Identify
prompt: Give one other function of an operating system.
answer:
• File management
• Peripheral management
• User management
• User interface

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the hardware component that carries instructions from memory to the CPU.
answer: Data Bus

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the reason why a higher clock speed is desirable.
answer: More instructions carried ot per second

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the name of a bus that is unidirectional.
answer: Address Bus

title: State/Identify
prompt: Some low-level programming languages use mnemonics. State the purpose of a mnemonic.
answer:
• To represent an instruction/command
• To make an instruction/command easy to read/write/learn/remember/understand
• An instruction in a set of instructions

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the type of low-level programming language that uses mnemonics.
answer: Assembly code

title: Characteristics/Features
prompt:
Mnemonics are one characteristic of some low-level languages.
Describe one other characteristic of a low-level language.
answer:
• A linked description such as:
• They are microprocessor/CPU/machine specific so they can manipulate the hardware directly
• They can be highly optimised to make efficient use of the hardware/execute more quickly/use minimal memory
• Each line of code is one instruction only Award responses that refer to machine code as a low-level language, such as:
• Machine code is written in binary so instructions can be processed directly by the CPU / do not need to be translated Award one mark for:
• Machine code does not need to be translated

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the name of the high-level programming language translator that executes a line of code immediately after translating it.
answer: Interpreter

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the name of the high-level programming language translator that executes the entire program before it will run.
answer: Compiler

title: Describe
prompt: Describe how data is stored on optical media.
answer:
A description to include two from:
A laser heats/burns (areas of a disk) , which creates lands/pits representing binary / 1s and 0s

title: Describe
prompt: Describe how data is stored on solid state storage
answer:
• A description to include two from:
• Data is stored using electronic circuits / transistors
• Electrons are trapped or released in a floating gate / memory cell
• The presence or absence of charge represents binary 1s and 0s

title: Describe
prompt: Describe how data is stored on a magnetic hard drive
answer:
• A description to include two from:
• There is a magnetic/chemical coating on surface of the media The magnetic state/polarity of the chemical can be changed to represent a 0 or 1

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the type of secondary storage that stores data as electric charges.
answer: SSD/ Solid State/ Flash

title: Reason
prompt: Give one reason the performance of a solid-state drive is not affected by fragmentation.
answer:
• A solid-state device has no moving parts
• Seek time is not affected by scattered data because it is read electronically

title: Advantages/Disadvantages
prompt: A code review is carried out by a programmer or an automated system and cost money. What is another  disadvantage of a code review by a programmer
answer: Adds additional/significant time (to the development cycle) Introduces human error Requires an extra person/resource/labour Requires more experienced programmer

prompt: A code review is carried out by a programmer or an automated system and cost money. What is another  disadvantage of a code review by a automated system
answer: May not identify all issues (that it is not programmed to find) May only find well known problems

title: Define
prompt: Define the term 'embedded system'.
answer:
• Forms part of another device / system
• Performs a single/dedicated/specific task

title: Define
prompt: Some program code requires translation. Define the term 'translation'.
answer: Converting (human readable) code to binary/machine code

title: Describe
prompt:
A slow magnetic hard disk may be affected by file fragmentation.
Describe fragmentation and the process of defragmentation.
answer:
• A description to include (to a maximum of 3, with at least one in each category): Fragmentation:
• Files are written to disk in blocks
• Blocks can be dispersed across the disk. Defragmentation:
• Defragmentation is when file blocks are rearranged on the disk
• All the blocks for one file are moved closer together
• All the free space is moved to be together

title: Describe
prompt: Describe how an embedded system that uses a sensor could control car windscreen wipers.
answer:
A description to include two from:
If set pressure levels / moisture levels are reached a switch could be turned on/off / windscreen wipers could be turned on/off / (wiper) motor speed altered .

title: Describe
prompt: Describe how an operating system organises files and folders.
answer:
• Uses a hierarchical/tree structure with a root node/directory
• Each position on the tree/path is a directory/sub-directory/folder, or file
• Each file has a unique path in relation to the root

title: Describe
prompt:
One function of an operating system is user management.

Describe one purpose of user management.
answer:
• A description to include:
• To provide access to the device by controlling who can log on to the device
• To allow a user to log on by checking the username/password
• By authenticating the user before allowing them to log on

title: Describe
prompt: Describe two ways a compiler differs from an interpreter.
answer:
• Two linked descriptions from:
• A compiler carries out translation once prior to execution whereas an interpreter carries out translation every time the program executes
• A compiler produces a stand-alone executable file whereas an interpreter is required each time the code is run
• A compiler reports errors after translation is complete whereas an interpreter reports errors as they occur

title: Describe
prompt: Describe two ways an operating system manages processes.
answer:
• Two linked descriptions from:
• Uses paging / allocates addresses/sections [of RAM] to share memory between processes
• Extends main memory by using part of secondary storage (as virtual memory)
• The memory of inactive processes is stored in virtual memory and swapped back when the process becomes active
• Uses scheduling algorithm to share processing time between competing processes

title: Describe
prompt: Describe two ways that a high-level language differs from a low-level language.
answer:
• High-level languages use instructions that look like English , whereas a low-level language uses mnemonics/binary code
• A high-level language statement generates many lines of machine code , whereas each line of low-level languages is/generates a single machine instruction
• High-level languages are general purpose/exist across microprocessors/CPUs/machine-independent , whereas a low-level language is microprocessor/CPU/machine specific
• High-level languages are abstracted from the hardware , whereas low-level languages manipulate the hardware directly

title: Explain
prompt: Explain one way an audit trail helps programmers create robust software.
answer:
• An audit trail improves accountability because it keeps track of who makes changes / when changes are made
• An audit trail makes going back to an earlier version easier because changes are tracked

title: Explain
prompt:
Some users are given administrator privileges.

Explain one way an operating system allows an administrator to manage users.
answer:
• A linked explanation such as:
• Users can be added/deleted so multiple people can use the same computer
• Edit user permissions so only specific users can securely access their storage space
• Control the amount of resources/storage each user can access so the limited storage on the machine can be shared
• Enforce user permissions so only certain users are allowed to install programs / access certain files

title: Explain
prompt: Explain the way a code review works.
answer: Code reviews are carried out by programmers/specialist software so that they can identify security bugs/security issues/bad practice

title: State/Identify
prompt:
The Internet of Things has allowed devices with embedded systems to function independently and to collect and exchange data without the need for humans.

One such device is a battery-powered mower for the garden.

(i)  Give one ways each category could be used by the mower.

Connectivity

Input

Process

Output
answer:
• Answer
One mark for each to a maximum of 4, with at least one in each category Connectivity:
• The mower could connect to a wireless/wired network
• The mower could have a GPS device . Input:
• A phone/desktop/software application could be used to schedule when it will work
• A map of the garden would be stored on the mower
• The mower would have sensors to know if it ran into things / if it was dark / if it were raining / if it ran outside the garden. Process:
• The microcontroller in the mower would run a program
• A map of the garden would be read by the program so the mower would know where to go
• The program would monitor the power status to know if it needed recharging. Output:
• The program on the mower could upload statistics/information back to the application
• The mower could have a digital readout / flashing lights to indicate status

title: Explain
prompt: Explain the best choice of secondary storage for the battery-operated mower.
answer: The mower should use solid-state secondary storage because it has no moving parts / can use very little power from the battery / is robust to bumps and knocks

title: Characteristics/Features
prompt:
When using a compiler to translate source code to machine code, the translation only needs to be done once.

Give three other features of a compiler.
answer:
• Translates the entire source file to machine code in one go / translates all the source code prior to execution
• Shows all syntax errors at the end of the translation process
• Produces a single executable/object code/platform-dependent output
• Separates the tasks of translation and execution

title: State/Identify
prompt:
The operating system manages peripherals.

Identify an additional piece of software that is required for the operating system to manage peripherals.
answer: Device Driver

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify an additional piece of software that is required for translating assembly code
answer: Assembler

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify an additional piece of software that is required for maintaining the performance of a hard disk.
answer: Disk defragmenter

title: Describe
prompt: Describe the purpose of an Analogue to Digital Converter (ADC).
answer: Converts analogue signals into digital data that a computer can process

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the feature of an optical disc that allows data to be read.

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the purpose of defragmentation software.
answer: Organising data

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify two reasons for using data compression.
answer: Reduces required storage space Reduces data transfer times

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the two items held in RAM according to the von Neumann architecture.
answer: Data and Instructions

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the type of secondary storage that uses a laser to read the disk.
answer: Optical disk

title: Advantages/Disadvantages
prompt:
A team of developers is using an audit trail when working on a program.

State two advantages of keeping an audit trail.
answer:
• One mark for each to a maximum of 2:
• There’s a record of who changed what when
• Identifies the point at which an error/security issue was introduced
• Enables the program to be rolled back to a previous state
• Improve accountability/produces robust code

title: Characteristics/Features
prompt:
A compiler translates source code to machine code. If the source code is edited, it must be recompiled.

Give two other characteristics of a compiler.
answer:
• Translates the whole program in one go
• Errors are reported at the end of translation
• The executable/machine code is architecture specific

title: Characteristics/Features
prompt:
An embedded computer system is part of a larger machine.

State two characteristics of embedded systems that make them different from general purpose computers.
answer:
• Limited processing resources
• Low power consumption
• Simple/robust operating system
• Low cost per unit
• Smaller in size
• Less storage
• Limited user interface

title: State/Identify
prompt:
Robust software must be free from vulnerabilities before it is released to users. Programming bugs are one type of vulnerability.

State two other types of vulnerability.
answer:
• Programming language specific vulnerabilities (directly manipulating memory)
• Security (vulnerability)
• Weak design
• Insufficient testing
• Bad programming practices (not following standards, using unvalidated 3rd party libraries)
• Inadequate validation (that fails to prevent incorrect/inappropriate data input)
• Inadequate authentication (that enables hackers to gain unauthorised access)
• Sensitive data not encrypted

title: State/Identify
prompt:
Algorithms can be written in a high-level language.

State what high-level code is translated to.
answer:
• Machine code
• Binary
• Object code
• Executable code / an executable

title: State/Identify
prompt: State two methods of source code translation.
answer:
• Compile/Compilation
• Interpret/Interpretation
• Assemble

title: Define
prompt: Define the term 'iteration'.
answer: Looping over iterm in a data structure

prompt: Define the term repetition
answer: Looping insturctions for a set number of times

title: State/Identify
prompt: Here is a relational operator used in a conditional test. count >index  State the two different results of evaluating a conditional test.
answer: True False

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the result of 5 / / 2

title: Define
prompt: Define the term 'syntax error'.
answer: • Code that breaks/violates the rules/grammar of the programming language Do not award credit for an example in isolation such as missing colon, there must be a definition

title: Explain
prompt: Explain a runtime error.
answer:
• The program crashes/stops because the operation the computer is asked to do is impossible
• The program crashes because the CPU cannot execute one of the instructions in the code For both marks, the expansion must follow/associate with the statement.
Do not award credit for an example in isolation such as division by zero.
Be careful not to award marks for syntax/logic error

title: Define
prompt:
Programmers use abstraction to model the real world.
Define the term 'abstraction'.
answer:
• A definition to include:
• The process of removing or hiding unnecessary details so that only the important points remain
• Programmers can focus only on the important details of a problem because abstraction allows them to ignore any detail that is not relevant

title: Define
prompt: Define the term 'decomposition'.
answer: Breaking down a problem/solution/system/algorithm

title: Define
prompt: Define the term 'subprogram'.
answer:
• One mark each for a maximum of 2:
• A subprogram is a self-contained block of code
• A subprogram performs a specific/dedicated task
• It can be ‘called’ by the main program or other subprograms, when it is needed

title: Describe
prompt:
Algorithms use arrays and records to hold data.
Describe a record.
answer: • A list / data structure / collection of elements/fields/values where each element/field/value may be a different data type / is related to the others For both marks, the expansion must associate with the statement

title: Describe
prompt:
A linear search algorithm can be used on both a sorted and an unsorted array.
Describe how a linear search algorithm operates on an unsorted array.
answer: • Start at the first position / Iterate / Traverse (through the array) , compare the item with the target , stop when the target is matched , or stop when the end of the list is reached (and the item is not matched)

title: Describe
prompt: Describe one difference between a syntax error and a logic error.
answer:
• A syntax error is caused by using the grammar/form/words of the programming language incorrectly , whereas a logic error is caused by an error in the design of the algorithm
• A syntax error causes the program not to interpret/compile/translate, whereas a logic error produces an incorrect/wrong result

title: Explain
prompt: Explain one benefit of using subprograms.
answer:
• An explanation to include two from:
• The subprogram may be used more than once in a program so that writing, debugging, testing will save time
• The subprogram performs one specific/contained task so it can be moved away from the main program code
• Subprograms for common tasks can be stored in libraries and reused in other programs so that they don’t have to be re-written

title: Explain
prompt:
Programmers use trace tables with algorithms.
Explain the purpose of a trace table.
answer: • It helps the programmer visualise the steps in a program / find errors/bugs / check the algorithm gives the correct output because they can see the value a variable holds at a given point in an algorithm . For both marks, the expansion must associate with the statement

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the term that means breaking a problem or solution down into smaller parts.
answer: Decomposition

title: Name
prompt: Name the type of operator for each example.       + *
answer: Arithmetic

title: Name
prompt: Name the type of operator for each example    AND OR
answer: Logical

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the worst case for a linear search algorithm.
answer: The target item is not in the list / is at end of the list

title: State/Identify
prompt: State three types of error that can occur in programs.
answer:
• Runtime
• Syntax
• Logic

title: State/Identify
prompt: State two benefits of subprograms.
answer:
• The subprogram code only has to be written once / saves development time
• The subprogram can be called many times (reusability)
• The subprogram only has to be debugged once
• It is easier to locate and debug errors
• Hides the details of how a function/procedure/code works (abstraction)
• Can be used by programmers who don’t have the knowledge to write them
• Can be grouped into libraries / can be shared with other programmers
• Makes programs easier to read / understand
• Reduces the overall size of code
• Problem can be decomposed into smaller sub-problems
• Allows a team to work on a project

title: Convert
prompt:
Computers manipulate binary patterns. Patterns can represent signed or unsigned integers.
Convert the denary number 57 to 8-bit binary.

title: Convert
prompt: Convert the binary number 0010 1101 to hexadecimal.
answer: 2D

title: Describe
prompt: Describe the process of converting a binary number to two's complement.
answer:
• A linked description such as:
• Flip all the bits and add one
• Copy/keep all the 0s from the right/LSB, up to and including the first 1 , then flip the remaining bits
• Flip all the bits from the left/MSB up to, but not including, the 1 nearest the right/LSB

title: Convert
prompt: Convert the binary pattern 0100 0010 to denary.

title: Convert
prompt: Convert the binary pattern 0101 1011 to hexadecimal.
answer: 5B

title: Convert
prompt: Convert the denary value +112 to 8-bit binary representation.

title: Give
prompt: Give the 8-bit binary two's complement representation of denary −73

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the number of unique values that can be represented with 6 bits.

title: Construct
prompt:
A file format uses a 100 × 600 table of 32-bit integers.
The file uses 1 kibibyte of additional data.
Construct an expression to show the number of bytes of storage needed to store the file.

title: Calculate
prompt:
In arithmetic, subtraction can be done by adding a negative number.
Calculate 18 − 8, using 8-bit binary and two's complement.
Convert the result back to denary.
Show all your working.
answer:
• 18 converted to 8-bit binary 0001 0010
• −8 converted to two’s complement 8-bit binary 1111 1000
• Addition performed correctly (1 mark for each nibble)○ 8-bit binary result of 0000 1010

title: Give
prompt:
The file size can be optimised by changing the colour depth.
Give the minimum number of bits that can store 5 colours.
answer: 3 bits

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the reason why decreasing the sample interval improves the digital representation of a sound wave.
answer: More samples in each sample

title: Construct
prompt:
Construct an expression to calculate the file size, in mebibytes, of a CD quality (44.1 KHz, bit depth of 16), two-channel stereo soundtrack that is 4 minutes long.
You do not need to carry out the calculation.
answer:
• One mark for each:
• Sample rate and bit depth = 44.1 × 1000 × 16
• Channels and time = 2 × 4 × 60
• Unit conversions = 8 × 1024 × 1024
• Numerator and denominator the right way around Example of an expression that gains full marks:((44.1 × 1000 × 16) × (2 × 4 × 60)) / (8 × 1024 × 1024)

title: Construct
prompt: Construct an expression to convert 40 681 930 227 712 bytes to tebibytes.
answer:
• Sight of 1024⁴ anywhere for number of bytes in a tebibyte
• 40 681 930 227 712 / 1024⁴

title: Convert
prompt: Convert the binary number 0100 1010 to hexadecimal.
answer: 4A

title: Convert
prompt: Convert the denary number –33 to 8-bit binary using two's complement.

title: Convert
prompt: Convert the denary number 82 to 8-bit binary.

title: Convert
prompt: Convert the hexadecimal number 2A to 8-bit binary.

title: Define
prompt: Define the term 'pixel'.
answer: The smallest single point of colour in an image / picture element / the smallest element of a bit-mapped image

title: Describe
prompt: Describe one way that changing the number of bits allocated to the colour depth determines how an image is represented.
answer:
• A description to include two from:
• Increasing the number of bits used for each pixel allows more colours to be represented in each pixel OR
• Increasing the number of bits allows more pixels to be used providing a greater level of resolution OR
• Decreasing the number of bits used for each pixel allows fewer colours to be represented in each pixel OR
• Decreasing the number of bits allows fewer pixels to be used providing a reduced level of resolution

title: Define
prompt:
Sound waves are converted to binary using sample intervals.
Define the term 'sample interval'.
answer: • The time / number of seconds / gap between samples / measurements

title: Describe
prompt: Describe one effect of using lossy compression to reduce the size of a file.
answer:
• (Removed) data cannot be restored / means that the original file/information cannot be fully recreated/represented
• When data is removed humans may perceive/interpret the image/sound/text/information differently

title: Describe
prompt: Data can be encoded using ASCII. Describe ASCII.
answer:
• A description to include two from:
• A standard
• For representing text/characters
• Allows data to be interchangeable between computers (from different manufacturers)
• Each character is mapped to a unique number/binary equivalent
• ASCII (encoding) uses 7/8 bits
• There are 128 unique characters (allow 256 for 128)

title: Describe
prompt:
Shifts are performed on binary patterns.
A logical shift right is performed on a pattern.
An arithmetic shift right is performed on the same original pattern.
Describe the reason the results will be different.
answer:
• An arithmetic shift fills from the left with a copy of the most-significant bit (MSB) , whereas a logical shift fills from the left with a 0
• An arithmetic shift keeps the most-significant bit (MSB) the same , whereas a logical shift always fills the MSB bit with a 0

title: Describe
prompt: Describe one reason that lossless compression is preferred to lossy compression for transmitting word-processed documents over a network.
answer: A lossless compression will allow the exact contents of the word-processed document to be reconstructed whereas a lossy compression will permanently remove data from the file

title: Explain
prompt: Explain the reason why at least nine bits are needed to store 300 different binary patterns.
answer:
• One from:
• 2⁹ gives 512 patterns whereas 2⁸ gives 256 patterns
• 2⁸ does not give enough patterns whereas 2⁹ gives more than enough patterns

title: Give
prompt: Give an expression to calculate the size of a bitmap image, not the size of the file that stores the image.
answer:
• An explanation to include:
• ASCII only represents English characters / Kana / Hiragana cannot be represented in ASCII because there are not enough bits
• With just 7 bits, only 128 unique codes can be generated, which is not enough to represent all the characters used in the written languages of the world
• The text has foreign characters and there are not enough bits in ASCII to represent them

title: State/Identify
prompt:
The address bus of a computer is 8-bits wide.
State the number of unique addresses that can be accessed.

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the result of a single logical shift left on the 8-bit binary pattern 0101 0101.
answer: Multiplication

title: State/Identify
prompt:
Two images are displayed on the same screen.
One image is 1280 × 720 pixels. The second image is 1920 × 1080 pixels. 
The second image has a higher resolution.
State one reason why the second image will be displayed in more detail.
answer:
• The number of pixels per (square) inch is higher
• The density of pixels is higher

title: State/Identify
prompt:
Analogue sound must be converted into a digital representation.
(i)  State the name for the height of a sound wave.
answer: Amplitude

title: State/Identify
prompt: State one benefit and one drawback of increasing the bit depth of audio.
answer:
• One mark for the benefit:
• Increases the accuracy of the representation One mark for a drawback from:
• Increases the amount of storage required
• Increases the time it takes to download the audio file

title: State/Identify
prompt:
The ASCII system is used to represent letters and symbols.
(i)  State the number of bits used to represent each letter or symbol in ASCII.

title: Give
prompt:
The ASCII code 65 represents the letter A.
Give the letter represented by the ASCII code 68.
answer: D

title: State/Identify
prompt:
After applying compression to a file, the original contents cannot be reconstructed fully.
State the type of compression used on the file.
answer: Lossy

title: Name
prompt:
Network protocols control the rules of communication.
(i)  Name a network protocol that transmissions from other electrical devices can interfere with and that can be blocked by walls.
answer: Wi-fi Bluetooth

title: Name
prompt: Name the network protocol used to download a music file from a server.
answer: FTP

title: Give
prompt:
Devices are connected to networks.
(i)  Give two reasons for connecting computers in a network.
answer:
• Can share files/data
• Can share applications/software
• Can collaborate
• Can share peripherals (printers, speakers)
• Can share connectivity (Internet connection, hotspot)
• Can access files from any computer / hot desk
• Central control/management (security, software updates, backup, remote support, users, remote monitoring)
• Allows communication (email, social media, video conferencing, online meeting, collaborative games)

title: Describe
prompt: Describe one way a local area network (LAN) is different from a wide area network (WAN).
answer:
• A description such as:
• A LAN covers a small (geographic) area / a WAN covers a large (geographic) area (2)
• A LAN uses infrastructure owned by one company / a WAN uses third-party infrastructure (2)
• A LAN connects individual devices / uses switches , whereas a WAN connects LANs / uses gateways

title: State/Identify
prompt:
A network has a speed of 17.08 megabits per second.
Identify the equivalent speed in bits per second.
answer: B 17 080 000A 17 080 is not correct because it is 17.08 multiplied by 1000C 17 080 000 000 is not correct because it is 17.08 multiplied by 1000³D 17 080 000 000 000 is not correct because it is 17.08 multiplied by 1000⁴

title: Define
prompt: Define the term 'latency'.
answer: The delay / amount of time between data/signal being sent and it being received

title: Give
prompt:
Networks are described in many different ways.
(i)  Give the type of network that covers a small geographical area.
answer: LAN

title: Name
prompt: Name the characteristic of a wireless network that is measured in metres.
answer: Range

title: Give
prompt: Give two disadvantages of a bus network topology.
answer:
• The whole network stops working if the backbone/cable is broken
• The number of collisions increases / the network will slow down as the number of devices/users increases
• A greater security risk (because all the nodes on the network see all the data packets)
• The network stops working if the terminators are missing/not working
• Only one device can transmit data at a time

title: Construct
prompt:
Construct an expression to calculate the minimum transmission rate required to transmit a 250 MiB file in exactly one hour.
There are 3600 seconds in an hour.
answer:
• Total number of bits:
• 250 × 1024 × 1024
• × 8 3600 as denominator Award all marks for the correct answer (582,542 bps).Example expression:(250 × 1024 × 1024 × 8) ÷ 3600

title: Construct
prompt:
Construct an expression to calculate the transmission rate, in megabits per second, required to transmit a 1.4 gibibyte file in 13 minutes.
You do not need to do the calculation.

title: Define
prompt: Network speed is the current rate of data transmission, measured in bits per second.Define the term 'bandwidth'.
answer:
• The maximum volume/amount of data that can be transmitted (in one second/unit of time)
• The full capacity of data that can be transmitted (in one second)

title: Describe
prompt:
A checksum works at the transport layer of TCP / IP.
Describe how a checksum is used to identify packets that have been corrupted during transmission.
answer:
• One for each, to a maximum of 3:
• A checksum formula is applied to the packet before it leaves the source computer
• The source-calculated checksum is added to the packet header
• At the receiving end, the same checksum formula is reapplied
• The new checksum is compared to the received checksum in the packet header
• If the received checksum and the newly calculated checksum do not match, a resend request is issued

title: Describe
prompt: Describe how a firewall protects a local area network (LAN).
answer:
• A description to include two from:
• Monitors/checks traffic using a set of rules / list of authorised or unauthorised computers, addresses, or protocols to decide if data is allowed into or out of the network

title: Describe
prompt:
High-speed fibre-optic cables form the internet backbone. Routers connect other networks to this backbone.
Describe how a router enables data to arrive at its destination
answer:
• Reads the destination/recipient’s IP address (in each packet)
• Uses a routing table
• Sends the data packet to the next router
• Uses the fastest/least congested route/pathway
• Keeps track / informs other routers of traffic conditions

title: Describe
prompt: Describe how the link layer of the TCP/IP protocol stack works.
answer:
• It converts the data into a suitable signal/electrical/radio for transmission on the media (Ethernet cable/Wi-Fi)
• It uses/adds a physical/MAC address for a source/destination
• Receives data from the network layer to send via physical hardware

title: Describe
prompt: Describe one difference between the POP3 and IMAP email protocols.
answer: POP3 deletes messages from the server when downloaded , whereas IMAP leaves them on the server when downloaded

title: Describe
prompt: Describe one disadvantage of using a bus topology.
answer:
• If the main cable fails / is damaged , the whole network will fail
• If more computers are connected , the transmission time is increased / increased chance of data collisions
• Every computer receives all of the data on the network , causing a security risk

title: Describe
prompt: Describe penetration testing.
answer:
• It is an authorised attack (black box / white box) on a network/system to identify security vulnerabilities
• It is a network/system attack carried out with the knowledge of an organisation to recommend measures that should be taken to improve security

title: Explain
prompt:
A factory has two file servers installed in an office.
A closed-circuit television system monitors the factory.
Explain one other method of physical security that could be used to protect the servers.
answer:
• (Digital/biometric) locks / magnetic card scanners / security personnel could be put on the office door to prevent unauthorised access
• Movement sensors , to activate an alarm/light
• Security lights/alarms , so that intruders would be scared off/identified
• Alarms/alerts could trigger because there is unauthorised access
• The servers/assets could have security tags , so that the owner can be tracked if stolen
• ID cards could be issued to all staff , to prevent impersonation/to allow unknown people to be challenged
• Warning posters could be positioned at entrances , to make people aware of shouldering/tailgating/two people entering together

title: Explain
prompt: Explain one benefit to a user of using IMAP to access emails.
answer:
• Emails can be accessed from multiple devices because IMAP does not remove/delete emails from the server
• Emails can be accessed through a browser because IMAP doesn’t need a client application to download messages

title: Explain
prompt: Explain one disadvantage of using a star network topology.
answer:
• A linked explanation such as:
• All communication could fail because/if the central device fails
• It can be difficult/expensive to set up because each device needs a cable to connect to the central device
• The number of devices that can be connected is limited because the central device supports a fixed number of connections

title: Explain
prompt:
A company stores statistics about its business on a server.
Explain one type of access to the statistics file a student on work experience at the company should be given.
answer:
• An explanation to include one mark for a type of access and one mark for a linked reason, such as:
• To recommend read only because the student cannot accidentally change/delete the data / because the student cannot share the data
• No access because the student cannot see any sensitive/irrelevant information

title: Explain
prompt:
A company needs to secure its network from attacks by its employees.
Explain the best choice of penetration testing the company should use.
answer:
• An explanation that includes the ideas:
• Permission is given to a person to carry out investigation of security issues in the network
• White-box / white-hat because system information is provided to the tester
• The company should give a security expert an ID and password and details of how the network is configured , and ask them to try to find vulnerabilities that would enable an employee to access, delete and/or leak sensitive data or install malicious software

title: Explain
prompt:
The performance of a network depends on speed, range, latency, and bandwidth. Bandwidth in a wireless network is constant because the capacity of the network is not affected by any other environmental factors.
Explain two ways that the performance of a wireless network can be affected by its environment.
answer:
• Wireless networks have a short range because walls and floors can block the signal OR
• Wireless/radio signals may not go very far because solid structures (thick walls, steel beams) block the signal
• Wireless networks can have high latency because they suffer from interference from other wireless networks or devices OR
• The performance of a wireless network can be adversely affected by interference from other devices because they can operate on the same frequency band / are high voltage, such as a microwave
• Wireless networks have low speed because all the devices must share the available bandwidth OR
• The more devices that are connected to the network, the more likely bottlenecks are to occur because they all want a share of the available bandwidth

title: State/Identify
prompt:
Data is split up into packets for transmission over a network.
Identify the item included in a packet header.
answer: Packet number

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the reason computers are connected in a network.
answer: To share peripherals

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the reason why all computers need a unique IP address.
answer: Identifies devices on a network

title: Give
prompt: Give two reasons for using a star topology rather than a bus topology.
answer:
• A star is more scalable than a bus because you can add extra devices without disrupting the network
• A star is more fault tolerant/reliable because a damaged cable/faulty device can be replaced/removed without disrupting the rest of the network
• It is easier to troubleshoot/isolate faults because all cables are attached to a central point
• A star is capable of handling higher volumes of network traffic than a bus

title: State/Identify
prompt: State one reason for splitting data into packets.
answer:
• Speeds up data transfer
• Reduces the reliability on a single pathway
• Reduces the impact of data corruption

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the name of an email protocol.
answer: POP3, IMAP or SMTP

title: State/Identify
prompt:
Each device on a network has a unique identifier that is used when sending or receiving packets of data.
State the name of the unique identifier.
answer: IP/ MAC

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the item included between the header and the footer in a data packet.
answer: Data being sent

title: State/Identify
prompt: State the network protocol used to request a webpage.
answer: HTTP/ HTTPS

title: Describe
prompt:
Large amounts of water are used to manufacture computer chips.
Describe one way this impacts the environment.
answer:
• The land/rivers/seas will be polluted if contaminated/uncleaned wastewater is released
• Homes/businesses/agriculture/wildlife/people may not have enough water if too much is taken from the rivers/reservoirs
• Water is polluted/contaminated (during the manufacturing process) and could pose a health risk
• Large amounts of energy are required (to extract/clean water) , resulting in more use of CO₂ / CO₂ contributes to global warming

title: Describe
prompt:
A replacement cycle is the time between the purchase of a device and the purchase of its replacement.
Describe one impact the length of replacement cycles has on the environment.
answer:
• Shorter replacement cycles lead to devices being disposed of more often , which leads to more e-waste/landfill/pollution
• Shorter replacement cycles lead to more manufacturing , which incurs increased extraction of metals/increased use of water to manufacture chips/use of fossil fuels
• Long replacement cycles mean devices are not disposed of , which reduces the amount of e-waste/landfill/emissions
• Long replacement cycles mean fewer devices are manufactured , which reduces the need for extraction of metals/the need for water to manufacture chips/less energy required

title: Describe
prompt:
Computer worms are a type of malware.
Describe one way that a worm can move from machine to machine.
answer:
• Worms make copies of themselves and send them to everyone in the computer’s email contacts list / send them via previous connections used by the computer
• Worms can spread (themselves) through emails and do not need a user to unknowingly distribute/execute them
• Worms self-replicate and spread without the need for a host file

title: Explain
prompt:
Computer programs control some aeroplane landings.
Explain one reason computers are not capable of safely controlling all aeroplane landings.
answer:
• The landing program may crash / display incorrect data / not deal with extreme scenarios (weather / wind / animal / visual / emergency) because:– the system could be out of date / have errors / bugs / not been tested enough – the scenario is beyond the range of what it has been programmed to respond to
• A computer’s input may be wrong/compromised because of a sensor/hardware/mechanical error
• A computer cannot make moral/ethical judgements because it is only capable of following instructions

title: Explain
prompt: Explain one reason why files should be backed up regularly.
answer:
• A linked explanation such as:
• It helps prevent loss of data because malware could deliberately delete data / because data can be deleted/corrupted accidentally
• It helps minimise disruption following a system failure because data can be restored
• Data can be restored because physical hazards (fire/flood) can damage storage devices

title: Explain
prompt: Explain one reason why software should be patched regularly.
answer:
• An explanation to include two from:It helps prevent unauthorised access to data
• because security issues could be missed in development
• because there could be interactions with other software
• because a malicious user could have published a vulnerability on the web
• because sometimes vulnerabilities only become apparent after code has been released to the public

title: Explain
prompt:
Robots use sensors to collect data about their surroundings in order to carry out actions independently.
Explain one way that a modern car is a robot.
answer:
• The wipers/lights come on automatically because sensors detect rain/darkness
• Speed is automatically adjusted / brakes are applied automatically / alarm sounded because sensors detect distance from other cars / obstacles / people
• The temperature is adjusted automatically because a sensor/thermometer monitors the change in temperature of the passenger compartment / car interior

title: Explain
prompt: Explain one way that a patent protects intellectual property (IP).
answer: A patent prevents someone copying/using/selling an invention because it gives the inventor the exclusive right to reproduce/use/sell it for 20 years A person/organisation that infringes a patent can be prosecuted because it gives the inventors the legal protection to defend their exclusive right

title: Explain
prompt: Explain one reason why an employee who is logged on to the company network should not click on a link in an email from an unknown source.
answer: An explanation to include two from:It increases the risk to data / reduces cybersecurity because the sender could be using social engineering techniques / the link could lead to a malicious website / could download malware

title: Give
prompt:
Consent must be obtained before organisations can use personal data.
Give two pieces of information that organisations must tell people when requesting consent to use their personal data.
answer:
• That they are giving consent
• That they can say no / refuse
• That they are not denied service if they say no
• What the data is being collected for
• What processing will be done on their data / purpose of the processing / how data will be processed
• That they can withdraw consent at any time
• That the data will be shared (with third parties)
• How long it will be stored
• That the data will be stored securely

prompt:
Data protection legislation sets out principles that organisations must follow.
Give two of these principles.
answer:
• One mark each for a maximum of 2:
• Lawfulness
• Fairness and transparency
• Purpose limitation
• Data minimisation
• Accuracy
• Storage limitation (time kept)
• Integrity and confidentiality (security)
• Accountability

title: Give
prompt: Identify the ethical issue associated with the use of artificial intelligence.
answer: Algorithmic bias

title: State/Identify
prompt:
A backup of a server is made each night. Only the files changed that day are backed up.
Identify the name of this type of backup.
answer: Inremental

title: State/Identify
prompt: Identify the two types of malware that replicate their code.
answer: Virua and Worm

title: State/Identify
prompt:
The source code of a software application is automatically copyrighted.
State one other method of intellectual property protection to control who can use a software application.
answer: Licensing

title: State/Identify
prompt: State one way users could reduce the environmental impact of digital technology.
answer:
• Reduce use
• Responsible disposal (to prevent leaking chemicals)
• Recycling
• Reuse
• Replace devices less frequently
• Use power-saving options (such as black screen)

title: State/Identify
prompt: State two methods of protecting intellectual property.
answer:
• Copyright
• Patents
• Trademarks
• Licensing
• Non-disclosure agreement
• Limit access to sensitive information
• Awareness training for employees

title: State/Identify
prompt: State two ways that a user can increase the useful life of a smartphone rather than throwing it away.
answer:
• One mark each for a maximum of 2:
• Use it as long as possible / don’t replace it
• Sell/give it to a company that will recondition it
• Give it away to a friend or charity
• Repair it if it breaks
• Keep the software updated

title: State/Identify
prompt:
Algorithmic bias could be caused by using inaccurate data to train a machine learning algorithm.
State two other ways that the data used to train an algorithm could cause algorithmic bias.
answer:
• One mark each for a maximum of 2:
• Not enough / insufficient data
• Biased / prejudiced data / not representative
• Non-aspirational data
